Problem:
Consider a two-variable system described by the equations \\(x' = x + 2y\\) and \\(y' = -2x + y\\). We explore the system's behavior under linear transformations and their combinations, denoted by matrix \\(M(t) = \\begin{bmatrix} \\cos(t) & -\\sin(t) \\\\ \\sin(t) & \\cos(t) \\end{bmatrix}\\), which rotates the state vector \\((x, y)\\).

If a state vector \\((x_0, y_0)\\) is initialized at time \\(t = 0\\) and transformed by \\(M(t)\\) before evolving, will the state \\((x(t), y(t))\\) be the same at time \\(t = T\\) as a vector that is simply evolved without transformation?
Explanation: The rotation transformation \\(M(t)\\) alters the initial condition by changing the direction and position of the vector. The effect of the transformation modifies how the system evolves, even though the underlying dynamics (described by the derivatives) remain the same. The transformed initial conditions result in a different trajectory than if the vector was just evolved under the differential equations.
